clause.title: Geometry Extension
clause.p: This clause defines the Geometry Extension parameterized Requirements class with the base IRI /req/geometry-extension. There is a single corresponding conformance class Geometry Extension, with the IRI /conf/geometry-extension. These Requirements define a vocabulary for asserting and querying information about geometry data, and define query functions for operating on geometry data.

As part of the vocabulary, RDFS datatypes are defined for encoding detailed geometry information as a literal value. A literal representation of a geometry is needed so that geometric values may be treated as a single unit. Such a representation allows geometries to be passed to external functions for computations and to be returned from a query.

clause.title: Rationale
clause.p:
Other schemes for encoding simple geometry data in RDF have been implemented. The W3C Basic Geo vocabulary
3 was an early (2003) RDF vocabulary for “representing lat(itude), long(itude) and other information about spatially-located things. Geo specifies WGS84 as the reference datum”. Further, many widely used Semantic Web vocabularies contain some spatial data support. For example, Dublin Core Terms provides a Location class
4 for “A spatial region or named place.” and schema.org provides a number of spatial object and geometry classes, such as GeoCoordinates
5 and GeoShape
6.
Many vocabularies such as the above provide little specific support for detailed geometries and only specify using the WGS84 Coordinate Reference System (CRS).

Since the first version of GeoSPARQL, many ontologies have imported GeoSPARQL. For example, the ISA Programme Location Core Vocabulary
7 whose usage notes provide examples containing GeoSPARQL literals and the use of GeoSPARQL’s “geometry class”. The W3C’s more recent Data Catalog Vocabulary, Version 2 (DCAT2) standard
8 similarly contains usage notes for geometry, bbox and other properties that suggest the use of GeoSPARQL literals.

Some of the properties defined in these vocabularies, such as DCAT2’s dcat:spatialResolutiondcat:spatialResolution have motivated the inclusion of new properties in this version of GeoSPARQL. In this case the equivalent property is hasSpatialResolutiongeo:hasSpatialResolutiongeo:hasSpatialResolution. The GeoSPARQL 1.1 Standards Working Group charter Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [CHARTER] contains references to a number of vocabularies/ontologies that were influential in the generation of this version of GeoSPARQL.

clause.title: GeoSPARQL and Simple Features (SFA-CA)
clause.p: The GeoSPARQL Geometry Extension is largely based on the ISO/OGC Simple Features Access — Common Architecture (SFA-CA) Standard Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [OGCSFACA]. Contrary to what the name may imply, SFA-CA is about Geometry and not about Features. SFA-CA describes simple geometry, meaning that geometric shapes are based on points and straight lines (linear interpolations) between points. Within a single Geometry, these lines may not cross.

Neither GeoSPARQL nor SFA-CA support full three dimensional geometry. Coordinates may be three-dimensional, which means that points may have a Z-coordinate next to an X- and Y-coordinate. The Z-coordinate then holds the value of height or depth. However, lines or surfaces can only have one Z value for any explicit or interpolated X,Y pair. This approach is often referred to as 2.5 dimensional geometry. Geometric functions working with Geometries that have Z values will ignore Z values in calculations and first project geometry onto the Z=0 level.

SFA-CA also describes M coordinate values that may be part of geometry encodings. The M value represents a measure, a value that can be used in information systems that support linear referencing. GeoSPARQL at the moment does not support linear referencing. Like Z values in coordinates, M values are to be ignored.

SFA-CA specifies a class hierarchy for Geometry. Although these classes are not part of the GeoSPARQL ontology, the GeoSPARQL SWG does publish a vocabulary of Simple Features geometry: . Geometry types defined in this vocabulary can be considered safe to use with GeoSPARQL. The two Geometry serializations that were specified in GeoSPARQL 1.0, WKT and GML, fully support all SFA-CA geometry types. However, the two Geometry serializations that were introduced in GeoSPARQL 1.1 do not. Some SFA-CA geometry types are not supported by either the OGC KML Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [OGCKML] or the GeoJSON format. For example, neither KML nor GeoJSON support the Triangulated Integrated Network (TIN) or Triangle geometry types.

clause.title: Recommendation for units of measure
clause.p:
For geometric data to be interpreted and used correctly, the units of measure should be known. Typically, the particular Spatial Reference System (SRS) that is associated with a Geometry instance will specify a unit of measurement. However, some elements of GeoSPARQL allow arbitrary units of distance to be used, for example the property hasSpatialResolutiongeo:hasSpatialResolutiongeo:hasSpatialResolution or the function buffergeof:buffergeof:buffer. In those cases it is advisable to make use of a well-known web vocabulary for units of measurement. Making the unit of measurement explicit will improve data interoperability. The recommended vocabulary for units of measurement for GeoSPARQL is the Quantities, Units, Dimensions and Types (QUDT) ontology
9 but others may be used, as long as they are well-described.

clause.title: Influence of Reference Systems on computations

fmt-title.semx: Influence of Reference Systems on computations

clause.p: A Geometry object consists of a set of coordinates and a specification on how the coordinates should be interpreted. This specification is known as a Spatial reference System (SRS). Taken together, coordinates and SRS allow performing computations on Geometry objects. For example, sizes can be calculated or new Geometry objects can be created. Some Spatial Reference Systems describe a two-dimensional flat space. In that case, coordinates are understood to be Cartesian, and Cartesian geometric computations can be performed. But Spatial Reference Systems can describe other types of spaces, to which Cartesian computations are not applicable. For example, if CRS <\http://www.opengis.net/def/crs/OGC/1.3/CRS84><\http://www.opengis.net/def/crs/OGC/1.3/CRS84> is used, coordinates are to be interpreted as decimal degrees of latitude and longitude, designating positions on a spheroid. The distance between two points using this CRS is different from the distance between two points that have the same coordinates but are based on a Cartesian CRS or other SRS.
To avoid erroneous computations involving Geometry, data publishers are recommended to clearly indicate the type of space that is described by the SRS.

clause.title: Parameters
clause.p: The following parameters are defined for the Geometry Extension Requirements.

dd.p: Specifies the serialization standard to use when generating geometry literals as well as the supported geometry types.

note.p: A serialization strongly affects the geometry conceptualization. The WKT serialization aligns the geometry types with ISO 19125 Simple Features Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [OGCSFACA] ISO 19125-1; the GML serialization aligns the geometry types with ISO 19107 Spatial Schema Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [ISO19107].

dd.p: Specifies the version of the serialization format used.

clause.title: Geometry Class
clause.p: A single root geometry class is defined: Geometrygeo:Geometrygeo:Geometry. In addition, properties are defined for describing geometry data and for associating geometries with features.
One container class is defined: GeometryCollectionGeometry CollectionGeometry Collection.

clause.title: Class: geo:Geometry
clause.p: The class geo:Geometrygeo:Geometry is conceptually derived from UML class Geometry in Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [ISO19107] which is that standard’s “root class of the geometric object taxonomy and supports interfaces common to all geographically referenced geometric objects”. geo:Geometry is defined by the following:

fmt-sourcecode.span: "A coherent set of direct positions in space. The positions are held within a Spatial Reference System (SRS)."
"Geometry can be used as a representation of the shape, extent or location of a Feature and may exist as a self-contained entity."

description.p: Implementations shall allow the RDFS class Geometrygeo:Geometry to be used in SPARQL graph patterns.

semx.p: Implementations shall allow the RDFS class Geometrygeo:Geometrygeo:Geometry to be used in SPARQL graph patterns.

clause.title: Class: geo:GeometryCollection
clause.p: The class GeometryCollectionGeometry CollectionGeometry Collection is defined by the following:

Membership of the general Spatial Object CollectionSpatial Object Collection that defines this class is restricted to instances of GeometryGeometry. geo:GeometryCollection members are to be indicated with the rdfs:memberrdfs:member property.NOTE:NoteClause 11.6.2, Note
There is no RDF/ontology relationship between this GeometryCollectiongeo:GeometryCollectiongeo:GeometryCollection class and the Simple Features Vocabulary’s sf:GeometryCollectionsf:GeometryCollection class since the former is a collection of geo:Geometry objects and the latter is to be used for compound geometry literals.
sf:GeometryCollectionsf:GeometryCollection instances can act as input or output of GeoSPARQL functions whereas GeometryCollectiongeo:GeometryCollectiongeo:GeometryCollection instances are more likely to be used for grouping geo:Geometry objects for other purposes.
Many geometry literal formats also have the ability to represent multiple geometries. Both the OGC Geography Markup Language (GML) and KML use a MultiGeometry type and Well Known Text (WKT) and GeoJSON use a GeometryCollection type. While the names of some of these objects are the same as this class’ and all the concepts are similar, there is also no RDF/ontology relationship between this class and these literals. This class contains whole geo:Geometry instances, which may have more information within them than just a geometry serialization.
As per the expected use of sf:GeometryCollectionsf:GeometryCollection instances mentioned above: the uses of multi-geometry literals and GeometryCollectiongeo:GeometryCollectiongeo:GeometryCollection instances is expected to be different too.

description.p: Implementations shall allow the RDFS class GeometryCollectiongeo:GeometryCollection to be used in SPARQL graph patterns.

semx.p: Implementations shall allow the RDFS class GeometryCollectiongeo:GeometryCollectiongeo:GeometryCollection to be used in SPARQL graph patterns.

clause.title: Standard Properties for geo:Geometry
clause.p: Properties are defined for describing geometry metadata.

description.p: Implementations shall allow the properties dimensiongeo:dimension, coordinateDimensiongeo:coordinateDimension, spatialDimensiongeo:spatialDimension, hasSpatialResolutiongeo:hasSpatialResolution, hasMetricSpatialResolutiongeo:hasMetricSpatialResolution, hasSpatialAccuracygeo:hasSpatialAccuracy, hasMetricSpatialAccuracygeo:hasMetricSpatialAccuracy, isEmptygeo:isEmpty, isSimplegeo:isSimple and hasSerializationgeo:hasSerialization to be used in SPARQL graph patterns.

semx.p: Implementations shall allow the properties dimensiongeo:dimensiongeo:dimension, coordinateDimensiongeo:coordinateDimensiongeo:coordinateDimension, spatialDimensiongeo:spatialDimensiongeo:spatialDimension, hasSpatialResolutiongeo:hasSpatialResolutiongeo:hasSpatialResolution, hasMetricSpatialResolutiongeo:hasMetricSpatialResolutiongeo:hasMetricSpatialResolution, hasSpatialAccuracygeo:hasSpatialAccuracygeo:hasSpatialAccuracy, hasMetricSpatialAccuracygeo:hasMetricSpatialAccuracygeo:hasMetricSpatialAccuracy, isEmptygeo:isEmptygeo:isEmpty, isSimplegeo:isSimplegeo:isSimple and hasSerializationgeo:hasSerializationgeo:hasSerialization to be used in SPARQL graph patterns.

clause.title: Property: geo:dimension
clause.p: The property geo:dimensiongeo:dimension is used to link a Geometry object to its topological dimension, which must be less than or equal to the coordinate dimension. In non-homogeneous collections, this will return the largest topological dimension of the contained objects.

fmt-sourcecode.span: "The topological dimension of this geometric object, which must be less than or equal to the coordinate dimension. In non-homogeneous collections, this is the largest topological dimension of the contained objects."

clause.title: Property: geo:coordinateDimension
clause.p: The property geo:coordinateDimensiongeo:coordinateDimension is defined to link a Geometry object to the dimension of direct positions (coordinate tuples) used in the Geometry’s definition.

fmt-sourcecode.span: "The number of measurements or axes needed to describe the position of this Geometry in a coordinate system."

clause.title: Property: geo:spatialDimension
clause.p: The property geo:spatialDimensiongeo:spatialDimension is defined to link a Geometry object to the dimension of the spatial portion of the direct positions (coordinate tuples) used in its serializations. If the direct positions do not carry a measure coordinate, this will be equal to the coordinate dimension.

fmt-sourcecode.span: "The number of measurements or axes needed to describe the spatial position of this Geometry in a coordinate system."

clause.title: Property: geo:hasSpatialResolution
clause.p: The property geo:hasSpatialResolutiongeo:hasSpatialResolution is defined to indicate the spatial resolution of the elements within a Geometry. Spatial resolution specifies the level of detail of a Geometry. It is the smallest distinguishable distance between adjacent coordinate sets. This property is not applicable to a point Geometry, because a point consists of a single coordinate set.
Since this property is defined for a Geometrygeo:Geometrygeo:Geometry, all literal representations of that Geometry instance must have the same spatial resolution.

clause.title: Property: geo:hasMetricSpatialResolution
clause.p: The property geo:hasMetricSpatialResolutiongeo:hasMetricSpatialResolution is similar to hasSpatialResolutiongeo:hasSpatialResolutiongeo:hasSpatialResolution, except that the unit of resolution is always meter (the standard distance unit of the International System of Units).

fmt-sourcecode.span: "The spatial resolution of a Geometry in meters."

clause.title: Property: geo:hasSpatialAccuracy
clause.p: The property geo:hasSpatialAccuracygeo:hasSpatialAccuracy is applicable when a Geometry is used to represent a Feature. It is expressed as a distance that indicates the truthfulness of the positions (coordinates) that define the Geometry. In this case accuracy defines a zone surrounding each coordinate within which the real positions are known to be. The accuracy value defines this zone as a distance from the coordinate(s) in all directions (e.g. a line, a circle or a sphere, depending on spatial dimension).

fmt-sourcecode.span: "The positional accuracy of the coordinates of a Geometry."

clause.title: Property: geo:hasMetricSpatialAccuracy
clause.p: The property geo:hasMetricSpatialAccuracygeo:hasMetricSpatialAccuracy is similar to hasSpatialAccuracyhas spatial accuracyhas spatial accuracy, but is easier to specify and use because the unit of distance is always meter (the standard distance unit of the International System of Units).

fmt-sourcecode.span: "The positional accuracy of the coordinates of a Geometry in meters."

clause.title: Property: geo:isEmpty
clause.p: The property geo:isEmptygeo:isEmpty will indicate a Boolean object set to true if and only if the Geometry contains no information.

fmt-sourcecode.span: "(true) if this geometric object is the empty Geometry. If true, then this geometric object represents the empty point set for the coordinate space."

clause.title: Property: geo:isSimple
clause.p: The property geo:isSimplegeo:isSimple will indicate a Boolean object set to true if and only if the Geometry contains no self-intersections, with the possible exception of its boundary.

fmt-sourcecode.span: "(true) if this geometric object has no anomalous geometric points, such as self intersection or self tangency."

clause.title: Property: geo:hasSerialization
clause.p: The property geo:hasSerializationgeo:hasSerialization is defined to connect a Geometry with its text-based serialization (e.g., its WKT serialization).

fmt-sourcecode.span: "Connects a Geometry object with its text-based serialization."

note.p: this property is the generic property used to connect a Geometry with its serialization. GeoSPARQL also contains a number of sub properties of this property for connecting serializations of common types with geometries, for example asGeoJSONas GeoJSONas GeoJSON which can be used for GeoJSON Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [GEOJSON] literals.

clause.title: Geometry Serializations
clause.p: This section establishes the Requirements class for representing Geometry data in RDF literals, according to different non-RDF systems.

GeoSPARQL presents specializations of the geo:hasSerialization property for indicating particular serializations and specialized datatype literals for containing them. It does not provide comprehensive definitions of their content since these are given in standards external to GeoSPARQL, all of which are referenced.

GeoSPARQL does present some Requirements for literal structure which extend the serialization-defining standards, for example the requirement to allow indications of spatial reference systems within WKT geometry representations.

example.p: GeoSPARQL’s expectation of RDF literal representations of geometry data is that it is related to the Simple Features Access (SFA) Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [OGCSFACA] ISO 19125-1 standard’s conceptualization of geometry which defines classes such as Point, Curve and Surface and specialized variants of them which it presents in a hierarchy. All SFA classes are represented in OWL in the Simple Features Vocabulary presented within GeoSPARQL as an independent profile element, see GeoSPARQL Standard structureGeoSPARQL Standard structure.

Some geometry representation systems given here do not use the same terminology as SFA, in particular Discrete Global Grid Systems. To know the extent to which geometry literal representations listed here support SFA, or map to SFA, please see their definitions.

clause.title: Well-Known Text
clause.p: This section establishes the requirements for representing Geometry data in RDF based on Well-Known Text (WKT) as defined by Simple Features Access Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [OGCSFACA] ISO 19125-1. It defines one RDFS Datatype: wktLiteralWKT LiteralWKT Literal and one property, asWKTas WKTas WKT.

clause.title: RDFS Datatype: geo:wktLiteral
clause.p: The datatype geo:wktLiteralgeo:wktLiteral is used to contain the Well-Known Text (WKT) serialization of a Geometry.

fmt-sourcecode.span: "A Well-known Text serialization of a Geometry object."

description.p: All RDFS Literals of type wktLiteralgeo:wktLiteral shall consist of an optional IRI identifying the coordinate reference system and a required Well Known Text (WKT) description of a geometric value. Valid wktLiteralgeo:wktLiteral instances are formed by either a WKT string as defined in or by concatenating a valid absolute IRI, as defined in , enclosed in angled brackets (< & >) followed by whitespace as a separator, and a WKT string as defined in .

semx.p: All RDFS Literals of type wktLiteralgeo:wktLiteralgeo:wktLiteral shall consist of an optional IRI identifying the coordinate reference system and a required Well Known Text (WKT) description of a geometric value. Valid wktLiteralgeo:wktLiteralgeo:wktLiteral instances are formed by either a WKT string as defined in Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [ISO13249] or by concatenating a valid absolute IRI, as defined in [IETF3987], enclosed in angled brackets (< & >) followed by whitespace as a separator, and a WKT string as defined in Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [ISO13249].

clause.p: The following ABNF Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [IETF5234] syntax specification formally defines this literal:

sourcecode.body:
wktLiteral ::= opt-iri-and-whitespace geometry-data
opt-iri-and-space = "<" IRI ">" LWSP / ""
sourcecode.fmt-sourcecode:
wktLiteral ::= opt-iri-and-whitespace geometry-data
opt-iri-and-space = "<" IRI ">" LWSP / ""

clause.p: The token opt-iri-and-whitespace may be either an IRI and whitespace (spaces, tabs, newlines) or nothing (""), the token IRI (Internationalized Resource Identifier) is essentially a web address and is defined in [IETF3987] and the token LWSP, is one or more white space characters, as defined in Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [IETF5234]. geometry-data is the Well-Known Text representation of the Geometry, defined in Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [ISO13249].

In the absence of a leading spatial reference system IRI, the following spatial reference system IRI will be assumed: <\http://www.opengis.net/def/crs/OGC/1.3/CRS84><\http://www.opengis.net/def/crs/OGC/1.3/CRS84>. This IRI denotes WGS 84 longitude-latitude.

description.p: The IRI <\http://www.opengis.net/def/crs/OGC/1.3/CRS84> shall be assumed as the spatial reference system for wktLiteralgeo:wktLiteral instances that do not specify an explicit spatial reference system IRI.

semx.p: The IRI <\http://www.opengis.net/def/crs/OGC/1.3/CRS84><\http://www.opengis.net/def/crs/OGC/1.3/CRS84> shall be assumed as the spatial reference system for wktLiteralgeo:wktLiteralgeo:wktLiteral instances that do not specify an explicit spatial reference system IRI.

clause.p: The OGC maintains a set of SRS IRIs under the http://www.opengis.net/def/crs/ namespace and IRIs from this set are recommended for use. However others may also be used, as long as they are valid IRIs.

description.p: Coordinate tuples within wktLiteralgeo:wktLiteral shall be interpreted using the axis order defined in the spatial reference system used.

semx.p: Coordinate tuples within wktLiteralgeo:wktLiteralgeo:wktLiteral shall be interpreted using the axis order defined in the spatial reference system used.

clause.p: The example wktLiteralWKT LiteralWKT Literal below encodes a point Geometry using the default WGS84 geodetic longitude-latitude spatial reference system:

sourcecode.body: "Point(-83.38 33.95)"^^<http://www.opengis.net/ont/geosparql#wktLiteral>

clause.p: A second example below encodes the same point as encoded in the example above but using a SRS identified by http://www.opengis.net/def/crs/EPSG/0/4326http://www.opengis.net/def/crs/EPSG/0/4326: a WGS 84 geodetic latitude-longitude spatial reference system (note that this spatial reference system defines a different axis order):

sourcecode.body: "<http://www.opengis.net/def/crs/EPSG/0/4326> Point(33.95 -83.38)"^^<http://www.opengis.net/ont/geosparql#wktLiteral>

description.p: An empty RDFS Literal of type wktLiteralgeo:wktLiteral shall be interpreted as an empty Geometry.

semx.p: An empty RDFS Literal of type wktLiteralgeo:wktLiteralgeo:wktLiteral shall be interpreted as an empty Geometry.

clause.title: Property: geo:asWKT
clause.p: The property geo:asWKTgeo:asWKT is defined to link a Geometry with its WKT serialization.

description.p: Implementations shall allow the RDF property geo:asWKT to be used in SPARQL graph patterns.

semx.p: Implementations shall allow the RDF property geo:asWKTgeo:asWKT to be used in SPARQL graph patterns.

clause.title: Function: geof:asWKT

sourcecode.body: geof:asWKT (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): geo:wktLiteral

clause.p: The function geof:asWKTgeof:asWKT converts geom to an equivalent WKT representation preserving the spatial reference system.

description.p: Implementations shall support asWKTgeof:asWKT as a SPARQL extension function.

semx.p: Implementations shall support asWKTgeof:asWKTgeof:asWKT as a SPARQL extension function.

clause.title: Geography Markup Language
clause.p: This section establishes a Requirements class for representing Geometry data in RDF based on GML as defined by the Geography Markup Language Encoding Standard OGC07-036. It defines one RDFS Datatype: gmlLiteralGML LiteralGML Literal and one property, asGMLas GMLas GML.

clause.title: RDFS Datatype: geo:gmlLiteral
clause.p: The datatype geo:gmlLiteralgeo:gmlLiteral is used to contain the Geography Markup Language (GML) serialization of a Geometry.

Valid gmlLiteralGML LiteralGML Literal instances are formed by encoding Geometry information as a valid element from the GML schema that implements a subtype of GM_Object. For example, in GML 3.2.1 this is every element directly or indirectly in the substitution group of the element {http://www.opengis.net/ont/gml/3.2}AbstractGeometry. In GML 3.1.1 and GML 2.1.2 this is every element directly or indirectly in the substitution group of the element {http://www.opengis.net/ont/gml}_Geometry.

description.p: All gmlLiteralgeo:gmlLiteral instances shall consist of a valid element from the GML schema that implements a subtype of GM_Object as defined in .

semx.p: All gmlLiteralgeo:gmlLiteralgeo:gmlLiteral instances shall consist of a valid element from the GML schema that implements a subtype of GM_Object as defined in OGC07-036.

clause.p: The example gmlLiteralGML LiteralGML Literal below encodes a point Geometry in the WGS 84 geodetic longitude-latitude spatial reference system using GML version 3.2:

sourcecode.body: """ <gml:Point srsName=\"http://www.opengis.net/def/crs/OGC/1.3/CRS84\" xmlns:gml=\"http://www.opengis.net/gml/3.2\"> <gml:pos>-83.38 33.95</gml:pos> </gml:Point> """^^<http://www.opengis.net/ont/geosparql#gmlLiteral>

description.p: An empty gmlLiteralgeo:gmlLiteral shall be interpreted as an empty Geometry.

semx.p: An empty gmlLiteralgeo:gmlLiteralgeo:gmlLiteral shall be interpreted as an empty Geometry.

description.p: Implementations shall document supported GML profiles.

semx.p: Implementations shall document supported GML profiles.

clause.title: Property: geo:asGML
clause.p: The property geo:asGMLgeo:asGML is defined to link a Geometry with its GML serialization.

description.p: Implementations shall allow the RDF property asGMLgeo:asGML to be used in SPARQL graph patterns.

semx.p: Implementations shall allow the RDF property asGMLgeo:asGMLgeo:asGML to be used in SPARQL graph patterns.

clause.title: Function: geof:asGML

sourcecode.body: geof:asGML (geom: ogc:geomLiteral, gmlProfile: xsd:string): geo:gmlLiteral

clause.p: The function geof:asGMLgeof:asGML converts geom to an equivalent GML representation defined by a gmlProfile version string preserving the coordinate reference system.

description.p: Implementations shall support asGMLgeof:asGML as a SPARQL extension function.

semx.p: Implementations shall support asGMLgeof:asGMLgeof:asGML as a SPARQL extension function.

clause.title: GeoJSON
clause.p: This section establishes a Requirements class for representing Geometry data in RDF based on Geographic JavaScript Object Notation (GeoJSON) as defined by [GeoJSON]. It defines one RDFS Datatype: geoJSONLiteralGeoJSON LiteralGeoJSON Literal and one property, asGeoJSONas GeoJSONas GeoJSON.

clause.title: RDFS Datatype: geo:geoJSONLiteral
clause.p: The datatype geo:geoJSONLiteralgeo:geoJSONLiteral is used to contain the GeoJSON serialization of a Geometry.

fmt-sourcecode.span: "A GeoJSON serialization of a Geometry object."

clause.p: Valid geoJSONLiteralGeoJSON LiteralGeoJSON Literal instances are formed by encoding Geometry information as a Geometry object as defined in the GeoJSON specification Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [GEOJSON].

description.p: All geoJSONLiteralgeo:geoJSONLiteral instances shall consist of the Geometry objects as defined in the GeoJSON specification .

semx.p: All geoJSONLiteralgeo:geoJSONLiteralgeo:geoJSONLiteral instances shall consist of the Geometry objects as defined in the GeoJSON specification Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [GEOJSON].

description.p: RDFS Literals of type geoJSONLiteralgeo:geoJSONLiteral do not contain a SRS definition. All literals of this type shall, according to the GeoJSON specification, be encoded only in, and be assumed to use, the WGS84 geodetic longitude-latitude spatial reference system ().

semx.p: RDFS Literals of type geoJSONLiteralgeo:geoJSONLiteralgeo:geoJSONLiteral do not contain a SRS definition. All literals of this type shall, according to the GeoJSON specification, be encoded only in, and be assumed to use, the WGS84 geodetic longitude-latitude spatial reference system ().

clause.p: The example geoJSONLiteralGeoJSON LiteralGeoJSON Literal below encodes a point Geometry using the default WGS84 geodetic longitude-latitude spatial reference system for Simple Features 1.0:

description.p: An empty RDFS Literal of type geoJSONLiteralgeo:geoJSONLiteral shall be interpreted as an empty Geometry, i.e. {"geometry": null} in GeoJSON .

semx.p: An empty RDFS Literal of type geoJSONLiteralgeo:geoJSONLiteralgeo:geoJSONLiteral shall be interpreted as an empty Geometry, i.e. {"geometry": null} in GeoJSON .

clause.title: Property: geo:asGeoJSON
clause.p: The property geo:asGeoJSONgeo:asGeoJSON is defined to link a Geometry with its GeoJSON serialization.

description.p: Implementations shall allow the RDF property asGeoJSONgeo:asGeoJSON to be used in SPARQL graph patterns.

semx.p: Implementations shall allow the RDF property asGeoJSONgeo:asGeoJSONgeo:asGeoJSON to be used in SPARQL graph patterns.

clause.title: Function: geof:asGeoJSON

sourcecode.body: geof:asGeoJSON (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): geo:geoJSONLiteral

clause.p: The function geof:asGeoJSONgeof:asGeoJSON converts geom to an equivalent GeoJSON representation. Coordinates are converted to the CRS84 coordinate system, the only valid coordinate system to be used in a GeoJSON literal.

description.p: Implementations shall support asGeoJSONgeof:asGeoJSON as a SPARQL extension function.

semx.p: Implementations shall support asGeoJSONgeof:asGeoJSONgeof:asGeoJSON as a SPARQL extension function.

clause.title: Keyhole Markup Language
clause.p: This section establishes the Requirements class for representing Geometry data in RDF based on KML as defined by Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [OGCKML]. It defines one RDFS Datatype: kmlLiteralKML LiteralKML Literal and one property, asKMLas KMLas KML.

clause.title: RDFS Datatype: geo:kmlLiteral
clause.p: The datatype geo:kmlLiteralgeo:kmlLiteral is used to contain the Keyhole Markup Language (KML) serialization of a Geometry.

fmt-sourcecode.span: "A KML serialization of a Geometry object."

clause.p: Valid kmlLiteralKML LiteralKML Literal instances are formed by encoding Geometry information as a Geometry object as defined in the KML specification Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [OGCKML].

description.p: All kmlLiteralgeo:kmlLiteral instances shall consist of the Geometry objects as defined in the KML specification .

semx.p: All kmlLiteralgeo:kmlLiteralgeo:kmlLiteral instances shall consist of the Geometry objects as defined in the KML specification Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [OGCKML].

description.p: RDFS Literals of type kmlLiteralgeo:kmlLiteral do not contain a SRS definition. All literals of this type shall according to the KML specification only be encoded in and assumed to use the WGS84 geodetic longitude-latitude spatial reference system ().

semx.p: RDFS Literals of type kmlLiteralgeo:kmlLiteralgeo:kmlLiteral do not contain a SRS definition. All literals of this type shall according to the KML specification only be encoded in and assumed to use the WGS84 geodetic longitude-latitude spatial reference system ().

clause.p: The example kmlLiteralKML LiteralKML Literal below encodes a point Geometry using the default WGS84 geodetic longitude-latitude spatial reference system for Simple Features 1.0:

sourcecode.body: """ <Point xmlns=\"http://www.opengis.net/kml/2.2\"> <coordinates>-83.38,33.95</coordinates> </Point> """^^<http://www.opengis.net/ont/geosparql#kmlLiteral>

description.p: An empty RDFS Literal of type kmlLiteralgeo:kmlLiteral shall be interpreted as an empty Geometry .

semx.p: An empty RDFS Literal of type kmlLiteralgeo:kmlLiteralgeo:kmlLiteral shall be interpreted as an empty Geometry .

clause.title: Property: geo:asKML
clause.p: The property geo:asKMLgeo:asKML is defined to link a Geometry with its KML serialization.

description.p: Implementations shall allow the RDF property asKMLgeo:asKML to be used in SPARQL graph patterns.

semx.p: Implementations shall allow the RDF property asKMLgeo:asKMLgeo:asKML to be used in SPARQL graph patterns.

clause.p: The property asKMLas KMLas KML is used to link a geometric element with its KML serialization.

clause.title: Function: geof:asKML

sourcecode.body: geof:asKML (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): geo:kmlLiteral

clause.p: The function geof:asKMLgeof:asKML converts geom to an equivalent KML representation. Coordinates are converted to the CRS84 coordinate system, the only valid coordinate system to be used in a KML literal.

description.p: Implementations shall support asKMLgeof:asKML as a SPARQL extension function.

semx.p: Implementations shall support asKMLgeof:asKMLgeof:asKML as a SPARQL extension function.

clause.title: Discrete Global Grid System
clause.p: This section establishes the Requirements class for representing Discrete Global Grid System (DGGS) Geometry data as RDF literals. The form of geometry data representation is specific to individual DGGS implementations: known DGGSes are not compatible or even very similar.
The Requirements class defines one RDFS Datatype and one property, .

clause.title: RDFS Datatype: geo:dggsLiteral
clause.p: The datatype geo:dggsLiteralgeo:dggsLiteral is used to contain the Discrete Global Grid System (DGGS) serialization of a Geometry.

fmt-sourcecode.span: "A textual serialization of a Discrete Global Grid System (DGGS) Geometry object."

clause.p: Valid dggsLiteralDGGS LiteralDGGS Literal instances are formed by encoding Geometry information according to a specific DGGS implementation. The specific implementation should be indicated by use of a subclass of the geo:dggsLiteral datatype.

description.p: All RDFS Literals of type dggsLiteralgeo:dggsLiteral shall consist of an IRI identifying the specific DGGS and a representation of the DGGS geometry data. The IRI shall be enclosed in angled brackets (< & >) followed by whitespace as a separator, and then the DGGS geometry data, formulated according to the identified DGGS.

semx.p: All RDFS Literals of type dggsLiteralgeo:dggsLiteralgeo:dggsLiteral shall consist of an IRI identifying the specific DGGS and a representation of the DGGS geometry data. The IRI shall be enclosed in angled brackets (< & >) followed by whitespace as a separator, and then the DGGS geometry data, formulated according to the identified DGGS.

clause.p: The following ABNF Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [IETF5234] syntax specification formally defines this literal:

sourcecode.body:
dggsLiteral ::= iri-and-whitespace dggs-geomety-data
iri-and-whitespace = "<" IRI ">" LWSP
sourcecode.fmt-sourcecode:
dggsLiteral ::= iri-and-whitespace dggs-geomety-data
iri-and-whitespace = "<" IRI ">" LWSP

clause.p: The token iri-and-whitespace is an IRI and whitespace. The token IRI (Internationalized Resource Identifier) is essentially a web address and is defined in [IETF3987]. The token LWSP is one or more whitespace characters, as defined in Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [IETF5234]. dggs-geometry-data is geometry data formulated according to the DGGS identified by IRI.
An example of a DGGS literal for the AusPIX DGGS could be:

sourcecode.body: "<https://w3id.org/dggs/auspix> CELL (R3234)"^^geo:dggsLiteral

clause.p: Where AusPIX is identified with the IRI https://w3id.org/dggs/auspix and CELL (R3234) is the representation of a geometry according to AusPIX.

note.p: What R3234 means, or the meaning of any other element within a DGGS’ geometry data is not handled by GeoSPARQL, just as GeoPSARQL does not delve into the internals of other Geometry formats such as WKT or GeoJSON.

description.p: An empty RDFS Literal of type dggsLiteralgeo:dggsLiteral, shall be interpreted as an empty geo:Geometry.

semx.p: An empty RDFS Literal of type dggsLiteralgeo:dggsLiteralgeo:dggsLiteral, shall be interpreted as an empty geo:Geometry.

clause.p: The following ABNF Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [IETF5234] syntax specification formally defines this literal:

sourcecode.body:
dggsLiteral ::= iri-and-space dggs-geometry-data
iri-and-whitespace = "<" IRI ">" LWSP / ""
sourcecode.fmt-sourcecode:
dggsLiteral ::= iri-and-space dggs-geometry-data
iri-and-whitespace = "<" IRI ">" LWSP / ""

clause.p: The tokens used above are as per the DGGS ABNF above.

clause.title: Property: geo:asDGGS
clause.p: The property geo:asDGGSgeo:asDGGS is defined to link a Geometry with its DGGS serialization.

description.p: Implementations shall allow the RDF property asDGGSgeo:asDGGS to be used in SPARQL graph patterns.

semx.p: Implementations shall allow the RDF property asDGGSgeo:asDGGSgeo:asDGGS to be used in SPARQL graph patterns.

clause.title: Function: geof:asDGGS

sourcecode.body: geof:asDGGS (geom: ogc:geomLiteral, specificDggsDatatype: xsd:anyURI): geo:DggsLiteral

clause.p: The function geof:asDGGSgeof:asDGGS converts geom to an equivalent DGGS representation, formulated according to the specific DGGS literal indicated by the IRI required to be present in the DGGS literal.

description.p: Implementations shall support asDGGSgeof:asDGGS as a SPARQL extension function.

semx.p: Implementations shall support asDGGSgeof:asDGGSgeof:asDGGS as a SPARQL extension function.

clause.title: Non-topological Query Functions
clause.p: This Requirements class defines SPARQL functions for performing non-topological spatial operations.

description.p: Implementations shall support the functions boundarygeof:boundary boundingCirclegeof:boundingCircle, metricBuffergeof:metricBuffer, buffergeof:buffer, centroidgeof:centroid, convexHullgeof:convexHull, concaveHullgeof:concaveHull, coordinateDimensiongeof:coordinateDimension, differencegeof:difference, dimensiongeof:dimension, metricDistancegeof:metricDistance, distancegeof:distance, envelopegeof:envelope, geometryTypegeof:geometryType, intersectiongeof:intersection, is3Dgeof:is3D, isEmptygeof:isEmpty, isMeasuredgeof:isMeasured, isSimplegeof:isSimple, spatialDimensiongeof:spatialDimension, symDifferencegeof:symDifference, transformgeof:transform and uniongeof:union as SPARQL extension functions, consistent with definitions of these functions in Simple Features , for non-DGGS geometry literals.

semx.p: Implementations shall support the functions boundarygeof:boundarygeof:boundary boundingCirclegeof:boundingCirclegeof:boundingCircle, metricBuffergeof:metricBuffergeof:metricBuffer, buffergeof:buffergeof:buffer, centroidgeof:centroidgeof:centroid, convexHullgeof:convexHullgeof:convexHull, concaveHullgeof:concaveHullgeof:concaveHull, coordinateDimensiongeof:coordinateDimensiongeof:coordinateDimension, differencegeof:differencegeof:difference, dimensiongeof:dimensiongeof:dimension, metricDistancegeof:metricDistancegeof:metricDistance, distancegeof:distancegeof:distance, envelopegeof:envelopegeof:envelope, geometryTypegeof:geometryTypegeof:geometryType, intersectiongeof:intersectiongeof:intersection, is3Dgeof:is3Dgeof:is3D, isEmptygeof:isEmptygeof:isEmpty, isMeasuredgeof:isMeasuredgeof:isMeasured, isSimplegeof:isSimplegeof:isSimple, spatialDimensiongeof:spatialDimensiongeof:spatialDimension, symDifferencegeof:symDifferencegeof:symDifference, transformgeof:transformgeof:transform and uniongeof:uniongeof:union as SPARQL extension functions, consistent with definitions of these functions in Simple Features Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [OGCSFACA] ISO 19125-1, for non-DGGS geometry literals.

description.p: Implementations shall support the functions metricLengthgeof:metricLength, lengthgeof:length, metricPerimetergeof:metricPerimeter, perimetergeof:perimeter, metricAreageof:metricArea, areageof:area, geometryNgeof:geometryN, maxXgeof:maxX, maxYgeof:maxY, maxZgeof:maxZ, minXgeof:minX, minYgeof:minY, minZgeof:minZ and numGeometriesgeof:numGeometries as SPARQL extension functions which are defined in this standard, for non-DGGS geometry literals.

semx.p: Implementations shall support the functions metricLengthgeof:metricLengthgeof:metricLength, lengthgeof:lengthgeof:length, metricPerimetergeof:metricPerimetergeof:metricPerimeter, perimetergeof:perimetergeof:perimeter, metricAreageof:metricAreageof:metricArea, areageof:areageof:area, geometryNgeof:geometryNgeof:geometryN, maxXgeof:maxXgeof:maxX, maxYgeof:maxYgeof:maxY, maxZgeof:maxZgeof:maxZ, minXgeof:minXgeof:minX, minYgeof:minYgeof:minY, minZgeof:minZgeof:minZ and numGeometriesgeof:numGeometriesgeof:numGeometries as SPARQL extension functions which are defined in this standard, for non-DGGS geometry literals.

note.p: The Requirements to support non-topological query functions for DGGS geometry literals are separated from the Requirements to support them for traditional geometry literals as it is expected that implementing these functions for DGGS literals will be significantly more difficult. This is due to the novelty of DGGS literals and thus the lack of existing software libraries for their manipulation.

description.p: Implementations shall support the functions of Requirement 39 for DGGS geometry literals as SPARQL extension functions, in a manner which is consistent with definitions of these functions in Simple Features , for non-DGGS geometry literals.

semx.p: Implementations shall support the functions of Requirement 39 for DGGS geometry literals as SPARQL extension functions, in a manner which is consistent with definitions of these functions in Simple Features Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [OGCSFACA] ISO 19125-1, for non-DGGS geometry literals.

description.p: Implementations shall support the functions of Requirement 40 for DGGS geometry literals as SPARQL extension functions which are defined in this standard, for non-DGGS geometry literals.

semx.p: Implementations shall support the functions of Requirement 40 for DGGS geometry literals as SPARQL extension functions which are defined in this standard, for non-DGGS geometry literals.

clause.p: Functions from this Requirements class are listed below, alphabetically.

clause.title: Function notes
clause.p: These notes apply to all of the following functions in this section.
An invocation of any of the following functions with invalid arguments produces an error. An invalid argument includes any of the following:

li.p: An argument of an unexpected type;
An invalid geometry literal value;
A non-fitting geometry type for the given function;
A geometry literal from a spatial reference system that is incompatible with the spatial reference system used for calculations; or
An invalid unit IRI.

clause.p: A more detailed description of expected inputs and expected outputs of the given functions is shown in Annex B.
Unless otherwise stated in the function definition, the following behaviors should be followed by all SPARQL extension functions defined in the GeoSPARQL standard:

li.p: Functions returning a new geometry literal should follow the literal format of the first geometry literal input parameter. If no geometry literal input parameter is present, a WKT literal shall be returned.

Functions returning a new geometry literal should follow the SRS defined in the literal format of the first geometry literal input parameter. If no geometry literal input parameter is present, a geometry result should be returned in the CRS84 SRS.

clause.p:
For further discussion of the effects of errors during FILTER evaluation, consult Section 17
<> 10 of the SPARQL specification SPARQL.
Note that returning values instead of raising an error serves as an extension mechanism of SPARQL.

From Section 17.3.1
<> 11 of the SPARQL specification SPARQL:

quote.p: SPARQL language extensions may provide additional associations between operators and operator functions; …​ No additional operator may yield a result that replaces any result other …​ . The consequence of this rule is that SPARQL FILTER s will produce at least the same intermediate bindings after applying a FILTER as an unextended implementation.

clause.p: This extension mechanism enables GeoSPARQL implementations to simultaneously support multiple geometry serializations. For example, a system that supports wktLiteralWKT LiteralWKT Literal serializations may also support gmlLiteralGML LiteralGML Literal serializations and consequently would not raise an error if it encounters multiple geometry datatypes while processing a given query.

note.p:
Several non-topological query functions use a unit of measure IRI. See the Recommendation for specification of units of measurementRecommendation for specification of units of measurement. Also, the OGC has recommended units of measure vocabularies for use, see the OGC Definitions Server
12.

clause.title: Function: geof:metricArea

sourcecode.body: geof:metricArea (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): xsd:double

clause.p: The function geof:metricAreageof:metricArea returns the area of geom in square meters. Must return zero for all geometry types other than Polygon. This function is similar to areageof:areageof:area but does not need a specification of measurement unit.

clause.title: Function: geof:area

sourcecode.body: geof:area (geom: ogc:geomLiteral, units: rdfs:Resource): xsd:double

clause.p: The function geof:areageof:area returns the area of geom. Must return zero for all geometry types other than Polygon. This function is similar to metricAreageof:metricAreageof:metricArea, which does not need a specification of measurement unit.

note.p: See the Recommendation for specification of units of measurementRecommendation for specification of units of measurement.

clause.title: Function: geof:boundary

sourcecode.body: geof:boundary (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): ogc:geomLiteral

clause.p: The function geof:boundarygeof:boundary returns the closure of the boundary of geom. Calculations are in the spatial reference system of geom.

clause.title: Function: geof:boundingCircle

sourcecode.body: geof:boundingCircle (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): ogc:geomLiteral

clause.p: The function geof:boundingCirclegeof:boundingCircle returns the minimum bounding circle around geom. Calculations are in the spatial reference system of geom.

clause.title: Function: geof:metricBuffer

sourcecode.body: geof:metricBuffer (geom: ogc:geomLiteral, radius: xsd:double): ogc:geomLiteral

clause.p: The function geof:metricBuffergeof:metricBuffer returns a geometric object that represents all Points whose distance from geom is less than or equal to the radius measured in meters. Calculations are in the coordinate reference system of geom. This function is similar to buffergeof:buffergeof:buffer, but does not need a specification of measurement unit.

clause.title: Function: geof:buffer

sourcecode.body: geof:buffer (geom: ogc:geomLiteral, radius: xsd:double, units: xsd:anyURI): ogc:geomLiteral

clause.p: The function geof:buffergeof:buffer returns a geometric object that represents all Points whose distance from geom is less than or equal to the radius measured in units. Calculations are in the spatial reference system of geom. This function is similar to metricBuffergeof:metricBuffergeof:metricBuffer, which does not need a specification of measurement unit.

note.p: See the Recommendation for specification of units of measurementRecommendation for specification of units of measurement.

clause.title: Function: geof:centroid

sourcecode.body: geof:centroid (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): ogc:geomLiteral

clause.p: The function geof:centroidgeof:centroid returns the mathematical centroid of geom. The centroid point does not have to be part of the surface it is derived from.

clause.title: Function: geof:convexHull

sourcecode.body: geof:convexHull (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): ogc:geomLiteral

clause.p: The function geof:convexHullgeof:convexHull returns a geometric object that represents all Points in the convex hull of geom. Calculations are in the spatial reference system of geom.

clause.title: Function: geof:concaveHull

sourcecode.body: geof:concaveHull (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): ogc:geomLiteral

clause.p: The function geof:concaveHullgeof:concaveHull returns a geometric object that represents all Points in the concave hull of geom. Calculations are in the spatial reference system of geom. Various implementers use parameters to calculate a concave hull. As such, two implementations may return different results from their concave hull functions for the same geometry. Implementers should make clear any default values used to calculate a concave hull in their documentation.

clause.title: Function: geof:coordinateDimension

sourcecode.body: geof:coordinateDimension (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): xsd:integer

clause.p: The function geof:coordinateDimensiongeof:coordinateDimension returns the coordinate dimension of geom.

clause.title: Function: geof:difference

sourcecode.body: geof:difference (geom1: ogc:geomLiteral, geom2: ogc:geomLiteral): ogc:geomLiteral

clause.p: The function geof:differencegeof:difference returns a geometric object that represents all Points in the set difference of geom1 with geom2. Calculations are in the spatial reference system of geom1.

clause.title: Function: geof:dimension

sourcecode.body: geof:dimension (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): xsd:integer

clause.p: The function geof:dimensionsgeof:dimensions returns the dimension of geom. In non-homogeneous geometry collections, this will return the largest topological dimension of the contained objects.

clause.title: Function: geof:metricDistance

sourcecode.body: geof:metricDistance (geom1: ogc:geomLiteral, geom2: ogc:geomLiteral): xsd:double

clause.p: The function geof:metricDistancegeof:metricDistance returns the shortest distance in meters between any two Points in the two geometric objects. Calculations are in the coordinate reference system of geom1. This function is similar to distancegeof:distancegeof:distance, but does not need a specification of measurement unit.

clause.title: Function: geof:distance

sourcecode.body: geof:distance (geom1: ogc:geomLiteral, geom2: ogc:geomLiteral, units: xsd:anyURI): xsd:double

clause.p: The function geof:distancegeof:distance returns the shortest distance in units between any two Points in the two geometric objects. Calculations are in the spatial reference system of geom1. This function is similar to metricDistancegeof:metricDistancegeof:metricDistance, which does not need a specification of measurement unit.

note.p: See the Recommendation for specification of units of measurementRecommendation for specification of units of measurement.

clause.title: Function: geof:envelope

sourcecode.body: geof:envelope (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): ogc:geomLiteral

clause.p: The function geof:envelopegeof:envelope returns the minimum bounding box — a rectangle — of geom. Calculations are in the spatial reference system of geom.

clause.title: Function: geof:geometryN

sourcecode.body: geof:geometryN (geom: ogc:geomLiteral, geomindex: xsd:integer): ogc:geomLiteral

clause.p: The function geof:geometryNgeof:geometryN returns the nth geometry of geom if it is a GeometryCollection that is defined in a literal type (such as in the case of a sf:GeometryCollection) or geom if it is a Geometry. This function is not applicable to the type geo:GeometryCollection, as elements in geo:GeometryCollection are not guaranteed to be ordered.

clause.title: Function: geof:geometryType

sourcecode.body: geof:geometryType (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): xsd:anyURI

clause.p: The function geof:geometryTypegeof:geometryType returns the URI of the subtype of Geometry of which this geometric object is an member. No attempt to reconcile different geometry subtypes across all support literals need be made.

clause.title: Function: geof:intersection

sourcecode.body: geof:intersection (geom1: ogc:geomLiteral, geom2: ogc:geomLiteral): ogc:geomLiteral

clause.p: The function geof:intersectiongeof:intersection returns a geometric object that represents all Points in the intersection of geom1 with geom2. Calculations are in the spatial reference system of geom1.

clause.title: Function: geof:is3D

sourcecode.body: geof:is3D (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): xsd:boolean

clause.p: The function geof:is3Dgeof:is3D Returns true if geom has z coordinate values. See [_GeoSPARQL_and_Simple_Features__SFA-CA_] for a description of GeoSPARQL’s limitations: currently it supports 2.5D and geometric functions ignore Z values in calculations.

clause.title: Function: geof:isEmpty

sourcecode.body: geof:isEmpty (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): xsd:boolean

clause.p: The function geof:isEmptygeof:isEmpty returns true if geom is an empty geometry, i.e. contains no coordinates.

clause.title: Function: geof:isMeasured

sourcecode.body: geof:isMeasured (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): xsd:boolean

clause.p: The function geof:isMeasuredgeof:isMeasured returns true if geom has m coordinate values, as used e.g. in linear referencing. See [_GeoSPARQL_and_Simple_Features__SFA-CA_] for a description of GeoSPARQL’s limitations: at the moment it does not support linear referencing and M values are ignored.

clause.title: Function: geof:isSimple

sourcecode.body: geof:isSimple (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): xsd:boolean

clause.p: The function geof:isSimplegeof:isSimple returns true if geom is a simple geometry, i.e. has no anomalous geometric points, such as self intersection or self tangency.

clause.title: Function: geof:metricLength

sourcecode.body: geof:metricLength (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): xsd:double

clause.p: The function geof:metricLengthgeof:metricLength returns the length of geom in meters. The longest length from any one dimension is returned. This is for example the length of a line from its beginning point to its endpoint or the length of the boundary of a polygon. This function is similar to lengthgeof:lengthgeof:length but does not need a specification of measurement unit.

clause.title: Function: geof:length

sourcecode.body: geof:length (geom: ogc:geomLiteral, units: rdfs:Resource): xsd:double

clause.p: The function geof:lengthgeof:length returns the length of geom. The longest length from any one dimension is returned. This function is similar to metricLengthgeof:metricLengthgeof:metricLength, which does not need a specification of measurement unit.

note.p: See the Recommendation for specification of units of measurementRecommendation for specification of units of measurement.

clause.title: Function: geof:maxX

sourcecode.body: geof:maxX (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): xsd:double

clause.p: The function geof:maxXgeof:maxX returns the maximum X coordinate for geom using the SRS of geom.

clause.title: Function: geof:maxY

sourcecode.body: geof:maxY (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): xsd:double

clause.p: The function geof:maxYgeof:maxY returns the maximum Y coordinate for geom using the SRS of geom.

clause.title: Function: geof:maxZ

sourcecode.body: geof:maxZ (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): xsd:double

clause.p: The function geof:maxZgeof:maxZ returns the maximum Z coordinate for geom using the SRS of geom.

clause.title: Function: geof:minX

sourcecode.body: geof:minX (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): xsd:double

clause.p: The function geof:minXgeof:minX returns the minimum X coordinate for geom using the SRS of geom.

clause.title: Function: geof:minY

sourcecode.body: geof:minY (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): xsd:double

clause.p: The function geof:minYgeof:minY returns the minimum Y coordinate for geom using the SRS of geom.

clause.title: Function: geof:minZ

sourcecode.body: geof:minZ (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): xsd:double

clause.p: The function geof:minZgeof:minZ returns the minimum Z coordinate for geom using the SRS of geom.

clause.title: Function: geof:numGeometries

sourcecode.body: geof:numGeometries (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): xsd:integer

clause.p: The function geof:numGeometriesgeof:numGeometries returns the number of geometries of geom.

note.p: This function returns 1 except in cases when it receives a collection type, such as an sf:MultiPointsf:MultiPoint, a sf:MultiLineStringsf:MultiLineString, a sf:MultiPolygonsf:MultiPolygon, or a sf:GeometryCollectionsf:GeometryCollection. The function does not apply to geo:GeometryCollectiongeo:GeometryCollection instances, as members of geo:GeometryCollectiongeo:GeometryCollection instances are not ordered.

clause.title: Function: geof:perimeter

sourcecode.body: geof:perimeter (geom: ogc:geomLiteral, unit: rdfs:Resource): xsd:double

clause.p: The function geof:perimetergeof:perimeter returns the perimeter of geom in the unit specified by the unit parameter for areal geometries. For non-areal geometries the result is equivalent to geof:hasLength.

clause.title: Function: geof:metricPerimeter

sourcecode.body: geof:metricPerimeter (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): xsd:double

clause.p: The function geof:metricPerimetergeof:metricPerimeter returns the perimeter of geom. It is similar to the function geof:perimeter, but always returns the result in meters.

clause.title: Function: geof:spatialDimension

sourcecode.body: geof:spatialDimension (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): xsd:integer

clause.p: The function geof:spatialDimensiongeof:spatialDimension returns the spatial dimension of geom.

clause.title: Function: geof:symDifference

sourcecode.body: geof:symDifference (geom1: ogc:geomLiteral, geom2: ogc:geomLiteral): ogc:geomLiteral

clause.p: The function geof:symDifferencegeof:symDifference returns a geometric object that represents all Points in the set symmetric difference of geom1 with geom2. Calculations are in the spatial reference system of geom1.

clause.title: Function: geof:transform

sourcecode.body: geof:transform (geom: ogc:geomLiteral, srsIRI: xsd:anyURI): ogc:geomLiteral

clause.p: The function geof:transformgeof:transform converts geom to a spatial reference system defined by srsIRI. The function raises an error if a transformation is not mathematically possible.

note.p: We recommend that implementers use the same literal type as a result of this function as the type of the input literal.

clause.title: Function: geof:union

sourcecode.body: geof:union (geom1: ogc:geomLiteral, geom2: ogc:geomLiteral): ogc:geomLiteral

clause.p: This function geof:uniongeof:union returns a geometric object that represents all Points in the union of geom1 with geom2. Calculations are in the spatial reference system of geom1.

description.p: Implementations shall support geof:getSRID as a SPARQL extension function.

semx.p: Implementations shall support geof:getSRIDgeof:getSRID as a SPARQL extension function.

clause.title: Function: geof:getSRID

sourcecode.body: geof:getSRID (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): xsd:anyURI

clause.p: The function geof:getSRIDgeof:getSRID returns the spatial reference system IRI for geom.

clause.title: Spatial Aggregate Functions
clause.p: This clause defines SPARQL functions for performing spatial aggregations of data.

description.p: Implementations shall support aggBoundingBoxgeof:aggBoundingBox, aggBoundingCirclegeof:aggBoundingCircle, aggCentroidgeof:aggCentroid, aggConcaveHullgeof:aggConcaveHull, aggConvexHullgeof:aggConvexHull and aggUniongeof:aggUnion as a SPARQL extension functions.

semx.p: Implementations shall support aggBoundingBoxgeof:aggBoundingBoxgeof:aggBoundingBox, aggBoundingCirclegeof:aggBoundingCirclegeof:aggBoundingCircle, aggCentroidgeof:aggCentroidgeof:aggCentroid, aggConcaveHullgeof:aggConcaveHullgeof:aggConcaveHull, aggConvexHullgeof:aggConvexHullgeof:aggConvexHull and aggUniongeof:aggUniongeof:aggUnion as a SPARQL extension functions.

clause.title: Function: geof:aggBoundingBox

sourcecode.body: geof:aggBoundingBox (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): ogc:geomLiteral

clause.p: The function geof:aggBoundingBoxgeof:aggBoundingBox calculates a minimum bounding box — rectangle — of the set of given geometries.

note.p: This function is similar in nature to envelopegeof:envelopegeof:envelope used to calculate the bounding box of just one geometry.

clause.title: Function: geof:aggBoundingCircle

sourcecode.body: geof:aggBoundingCircle (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): ogc:geomLiteral

clause.p: The function geof:aggBoundingCirclegeof:aggBoundingCircle calculates a minimum bounding circle of the set of given geometries.

note.p: This function is similar in name to boundingCirclegeof:boundingCirclegeof:boundingCircle used to calculate the bounding circle of just one geometry.

clause.title: Function: geof:aggCentroid

sourcecode.body: geof:aggCentroid (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): ogc:geomLiteral

clause.p: The function geof:aggCentroidgeof:aggCentroid calculates the centroid of the set of given geometries.

note.p: This function is similar in name to centroidgeof:centroidgeof:centroid used to calculate the centroid of just one geometry.

clause.title: Function: geof:aggConcaveHull

sourcecode.body: geof:aggConcaveHull (geom: ogc:geomLiteral, targetPercent: xsd:double): ogc:geomLiteral

clause.p: The function geof:aggConcaveHullgeof:aggConcaveHull calculates the concave hull of the set of given geometries.

note.p: This function is similar in name to concaveHullgeof:concaveHullgeof:concaveHull used to calculate the concave hull of just one geometry.

clause.title: Function: geof:aggConvexHull

sourcecode.body: geof:aggConvexHull (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): ogc:geomLiteral

clause.p: The function geof:aggConvexHullgeof:aggConvexHull calculates the convex hull of the set of given geometries.

note.p: This function is similar in name to convexHullgeof:convexHullgeof:convexHull used to calculate the convex hull of just one geometry.

clause.title: Function: geof:aggUnion

sourcecode.body: geof:aggUnion (geom: ogc:geomLiteral): ogc:geomLiteral

clause.p:
The function geof:aggUniongeof:aggUnion calculates the union of the set of given geometries.NOTE:NoteClause 11.10.6, Note
This function is similar in name to uniongeof:uniongeof:union used to calculate the union of just two geometries.

clause.title: Geometry Topology Extension
clause.p: This clause establishes the Geometry Topology Extension parameterized Requirements class with base IRI /req/geometry-topology-extension, which defines a collection of topological query functions that operate on geometry literals. These Requirements are parameterized to give implementations flexibility in the topological relation families and geometry serializations that they choose to support. These Requirements have a single corresponding conformance class Geometry Topology Extension, with IRI /conf/geometry-topology-extension.

The Dimensionally Extended Nine Intersection Model (DE-9IM) Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [DE-9IM] has been used to define the relation tested by the query functions introduced in this section. Each query function is associated with a defining DE-9IM intersection pattern. Possible pattern values are:

li.p: -1 (empty)
F (false) = {-1}

clause.p: In the following descriptions, the notation X/Y is used to denote applying a spatial relation to geometry types X and Y (i.e., x relation y where x is of type X and y is of type Y). The symbol P is used for 0-dimensional geometries (e.g., points). The symbol L is used for 1- dimensional geometries (e.g. lines), and the symbol A is used for 2-dimensional geometries (e.g. polygons). Consult the Simple Features specification Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [OGCSFACA] ISO 19125-1 for a more detailed description of DE-9IM intersection patterns.

li.p: relation_family: Specifies the set of topological spatial relations to support.
serialization: Specifies the serialization standard to use for geometry literals.
version: Specifies the version of the serialization format used.

description.p: Implementations shall support relategeof:relate as a SPARQL extension function, consistent with the relate operator defined in Simple Features .

semx.p: Implementations shall support relategeof:relategeof:relate as a SPARQL extension function, consistent with the relate operator defined in Simple Features Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [OGCSFACA] ISO 19125-1.

sourcecode.body: geof:relate (geom1: ogc:geomLiteral, geom2: ogc:geomLiteral, pattern-matrix: xsd:string): xsd:boolean

example.p: Returns true if the spatial relationship between geom1 and geom2 corresponds to one with acceptable values for the specified pattern-matrix. Otherwise, this function returns false. pattern-matrix represents a DE-9IM intersection pattern consisting of T (true) and F (false) values. The spatial reference system for geom1 is used for spatial calculations.
=== Simple Features Relation Family
This clause establishes Requirements for the Simple Features relation family.

description.p: Implementations shall support geof:sfEquals, geof:sfDisjoint, geof:sfIntersects, geof:sfTouches, geof:sfCrosses, geof:sfWithin, geof:sfContains and geof:sfOverlaps as SPARQL extension functions, consistent with their corresponding DE-9IM intersection patterns, as defined by Simple Features .

semx.p: Implementations shall support geof:sfEqualsgeof:sfEquals, geof:sfDisjointgeof:sfDisjoint, geof:sfIntersectsgeof:sfIntersects, geof:sfTouchesgeof:sfTouches, geof:sfCrossesgeof:sfCrosses, geof:sfWithingeof:sfWithin, geof:sfContainsgeof:sfContains and geof:sfOverlapsgeof:sfOverlaps as SPARQL extension functions, consistent with their corresponding DE-9IM intersection patterns, as defined by Simple Features Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [OGCSFACA] ISO 19125-1.

example.p: Boolean query functions defined for the Simple Features relation family, along with their associated DE-9IM intersection patterns, are shown in Table 6 below. Multi-row intersection patterns should be interpreted as a logical OR of each row. Each function accepts two arguments (geom1 and geom2) of the geometry literal serialization type specified by serialization and version. Each function returns an xsd:booleanxsd:boolean value of true if the specified relation exists between geom1 and geom2 and returns false otherwise. In each case, the spatial reference system of geom1 is used for spatial calculations.

td.tt: (T*T***T**) for P/L, P/A, L/A; (0*T***T**) for L/L

example.p: === Egenhofer Relation Family

This clause establishes Requirements for the Egenhofer relation family. Consult references Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [FORMAL] and Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [CATEG] for a more detailed discussion of Egenhofer relations.

description.p: Implementations shall support geof:ehEquals, geof:ehDisjoint, geof:ehMeet, geof:ehOverlap, geof:ehCovers, geof:ehCoveredBy, geof:ehInside and geof:ehContains as SPARQL extension functions, consistent with their corresponding DE-9IM intersection patterns, as defined by Simple Features .

semx.p: Implementations shall support geof:ehEqualsgeof:ehEquals, geof:ehDisjointgeof:ehDisjoint, geof:ehMeetgeof:ehMeet, geof:ehOverlapgeof:ehOverlap, geof:ehCoversgeof:ehCovers, geof:ehCoveredBygeof:ehCoveredBy, geof:ehInsidegeof:ehInside and geof:ehContainsgeof:ehContains as SPARQL extension functions, consistent with their corresponding DE-9IM intersection patterns, as defined by Simple Features Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [OGCSFACA] ISO 19125-1.

example.p: Boolean query functions defined for the Egenhofer relation family, along with their associated DE-9IM intersection patterns, are shown in Table 7 below. Multi-row intersection patterns should be interpreted as a logical OR of each row. Each function accepts two arguments (geom1 and geom2) of the geometry literal serialization type specified by serialization and version. Each function returns an xsd:booleanxsd:boolean value of true if the specified relation exists between geom1 and geom2 and returns false otherwise. In each case, the spatial reference system of geom1 is used for spatial calculations.
=== RCC8 Relation Family

This clause establishes Requirements for the RCC8 relation family. Consult references Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [QUAL] and Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [LOGIC] for a more detailed discussion of RCC8 relations.

description.p: Implementations shall support geof:rcc8eq, geof:rcc8dc, geof:rcc8ec, geof:rcc8po, geof:rcc8tppi, geof:rcc8tpp, geof:rcc8ntpp and geof:rcc8ntppi as SPARQL extension functions, consistent with their corresponding DE-9IM intersection patterns, as defined by Simple Features .

semx.p: Implementations shall support geof:rcc8eqgeof:rcc8eq, geof:rcc8dcgeof:rcc8dc, geof:rcc8ecgeof:rcc8ec, geof:rcc8pogeof:rcc8po, geof:rcc8tppigeof:rcc8tppi, geof:rcc8tppgeof:rcc8tpp, geof:rcc8ntppgeof:rcc8ntpp and geof:rcc8ntppigeof:rcc8ntppi as SPARQL extension functions, consistent with their corresponding DE-9IM intersection patterns, as defined by Simple Features Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [OGCSFACA] ISO 19125-1.

example.p: Boolean query functions defined for the RCC8 relation family, along with their associated DE-9IM intersection patterns, are shown in Table 8 below. Each function accepts two arguments (geom1 and geom2) of the geometry literal serialization type specified by serialization and version. Each function returns an xsd:booleanxsd:boolean value of true if the specified relation exists between geom1 and geom2 and returns false otherwise. In each case, the spatial reference system of geom1 is used for spatial calculations.
== RDFS Entailment Extension

This clause establishes the RDFS Entailment Extension parameterized Requirements class with base IRI /req/rdfs-entailment-extension, which defines a mechanism for matching implicitly-derived RDF triples in GeoSPARQL queries. This class is parameterized to give implementations flexibility in the topological relation families and geometry types that they choose to support. These Requirements have a single corresponding conformance class RDFS Entailment Extension, with IRI /conf/rdfs-entailment-extension.
=== Parameters

li.p: relation_family: Specifies the set of topological spatial relations to support.
serialization: Specifies the serialization standard to use for geometry literals.
version: Specifies the version of the serialization format used.

example.p: === Common Requirements
The basic mechanism for supporting RDFS entailment has been defined by the W3C SPARQL 1.1 RDFS Entailment Regime SPARQLENT.

description.p: Basic graph pattern matching shall use the semantics defined by the RDFS Entailment Regime .

semx.p: Basic graph pattern matching shall use the semantics defined by the RDFS Entailment Regime SPARQLENT.

example.p: === WKT Serialization
This section establishes the requirements for representing geometry data in RDF based on WKT as defined by Simple Features Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [OGCSFACA] ISO 19125-1.
==== Geometry Class Hierarchy

The Simple Features specification presents a geometry class hierarchy. It is straightforward to represent this class hierarchy in RDFS and OWL by constructing IRIs for geometry classes using the following pattern: http://www.opengis.net/ont/sf#{geometry class} and by asserting appropriate rdfs:subClassOfrdfs:subClassOf statements. The Simple Features Vocabulary resource within GeoSPARQL 1.1 (sibling resource to this specification) does this. The following list gives the class hierarchy with each indented item being a subclass of the item in the line above. The class hierarchy starts with GeoSPARQL’s geo:Geometry class of which sf:Geometrysf:Geometry is a subclass:

sourcecode.body: geo:Geometry sf:Geometry sf:Curve sf:LineString sf:Line sf:LinearRing sf:GeometryCollection sf:MultiCurve sf:MultiLineString sf:MultiPoint sf:MultiSurface sf:MultiPolygon sf:Point sf:Surface sf:Polygon sf:Envelope sf:Triangle sf:PolyhedralSurface sf:TIN

example.p: The following example RDF snippet below encodes the Simple Features vocabulary Polygon class:

fmt-sourcecode.span: "A planar surface defined by 1 exterior boundary and 0 or more interior boundaries"

description.p: Implementations shall support graph patterns involving terms from an RDFS/OWL class hierarchy of geometry types consistent with the one in the specified version of Simple Features .

semx.p: Implementations shall support graph patterns involving terms from an RDFS/OWL class hierarchy of geometry types consistent with the one in the specified version of Simple Features Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [OGCSFACA] ISO 19125-1.

example.p: === GML Serialization
This section establishes Requirements for representing geometry data in RDF based on GML as defined by Geography Markup Language Encoding Standard OGC07-036.
==== Geometry Class Hierarchy

An RDF/OWL class hierarchy can be generated from the GML schema that implements GM_Object by constructing IRIs for geometry classes using the following pattern: http://www.opengis.net/ont/gml#{GML Element} and by asserting appropriate rdfs:subClassOfrdfs:subClassOf statements.
The example RDF snippet below encodes the Polygon class from GML 3.2.

fmt-sourcecode.span: "A planar surface defined by 1 exterior boundary and 0 or more interior boundaries."

description.p: Implementations shall support graph patterns involving terms from an RDFS/OWL class hierarchy of geometry types consistent with the GML schema that implements GM_Object using the specified version of GML .

semx.p: Implementations shall support graph patterns involving terms from an RDFS/OWL class hierarchy of geometry types consistent with the GML schema that implements GM_Object using the specified version of GML OGC07-036.

example.p: == Query Rewrite Extension

This clause establishes the Query Rewrite Extension parameterized Requirements class with base IRI /req/query-rewrite-extension, which has a single corresponding conformance class Query Rewrite Extension, with IRI /conf/query-rewrite-extension. These Requirements define a set of RIF rules Clause 12.2, Definition List 3: [RIF] that use topological extension functions defined in [geometry_extension] to establish the existence of direct topological predicates defined in [vocabulary_extension]. One possible implementation strategy is to transform a given query by expanding a triple pattern involving a direct spatial predicate into a series of triple patterns and an invocation of the corresponding extension function as specified in the RIF rule.

The following rule specified using the RIF Core Dialect RIFCORE and shown in Presentation Syntax is used as a template to describe rules in the remainder of this clause. ogc:relation is used as a placeholder for the spatial relation IRIs defined in Clause 7, and ogc:function is used as a placeholder for the spatial functions defined in [geometry_extension]. ogc:asGeomLiteral is used to indicate one of the properties that link geo:Geometry instances to serialisations, such as geo:asWKTgeo:asWKT or geo:asGeoJSONgeo:asGeoJSON. The variables ?so1 & ?so2 represent geo:SpatialObjectgeo:SpatialObject instances (either geo:Featuregeo:Feature or geo:Geometrygeo:Geometry instances), ?g1 & ?g2 geo:Geometrygeo:Geometry instances only and ?g1Serial & ?g2Serial represent geo:Geometrygeo:Geometry instance serializations, e.g. geo:asWKTgeo:asWKT etc. literals.

sourcecode.body: Forall ?so1 ?so2 ?g1 ?g2 ?g1Serial ?g2Serial ( ?so1[ogc:relation->?so2] :- Or ( And ( # feature - feature rule ?so1[geo:hasDefaultGeometry->?g1] ?so2[geo:hasDefaultGeometry->?g2] ?g1[ogc:asGeomLiteral->?g1Serial] ?g2[ogc:asGeomLiteral->?g2Serial] External(ogc:function(?g1Serial, ?g2Serial)) ) And ( # feature - geometry rule ?so1[geo:hasDefaultGeometry->?g1] ?g1[ogc:asGeomLiteral->?g1Serial] ?so2[ogc:asGeomLiteral->?g2Serial] External(ogc:function(?g1Serial, ?g2Serial)) ) And ( # geometry - feature rule ?so1[ogc:asGeomLiteral->?g1Serial] ?so2[geo:hasDefaultGeometry->?g2] ?g2[ogc:asGeomLiteral->?g2Serial] External(ogc:function(?g1Serial, ?g2Serial)) ) And ( # geometry - geometry rule ?so1[ogc:asGeomLiteral->?g1Serial] ?so2[ogc:asGeomLiteral->?g2Serial] External(ogc:function(?g1Serial, ?g2Serial)) ) ) )
sourcecode.fmt-sourcecode: Forall ?so1 ?so2 ?g1 ?g2 ?g1Serial ?g2Serial ( ?so1[ogc:relation->?so2] :- Or ( And ( # feature - feature rule ?so1[geo:hasDefaultGeometry->?g1] ?so2[geo:hasDefaultGeometry->?g2] ?g1[ogc:asGeomLiteral->?g1Serial] ?g2[ogc:asGeomLiteral->?g2Serial] External(ogc:function(?g1Serial, ?g2Serial)) ) And ( # feature - geometry rule ?so1[geo:hasDefaultGeometry->?g1] ?g1[ogc:asGeomLiteral->?g1Serial] ?so2[ogc:asGeomLiteral->?g2Serial] External(ogc:function(?g1Serial, ?g2Serial)) ) And ( # geometry - feature rule ?so1[ogc:asGeomLiteral->?g1Serial] ?so2[geo:hasDefaultGeometry->?g2] ?g2[ogc:asGeomLiteral->?g2Serial] External(ogc:function(?g1Serial, ?g2Serial)) ) And ( # geometry - geometry rule ?so1[ogc:asGeomLiteral->?g1Serial] ?so2[ogc:asGeomLiteral->?g2Serial] External(ogc:function(?g1Serial, ?g2Serial)) ) ) )

example.p: === Parameters

li.p: relation_family: Specifies the set of topological spatial relations to support.
serialization: Specifies the serialization standard to use for geometry literals.
version: Specifies the version of the serialization format used.

example.p: === Simple Features Relation Family
This clause defines Requirements for the Simple Features relation family. Table 9 specifies the function and property substitutions for each rule in the Simple Features relation family.

description.p: Basic graph pattern matching shall use the semantics defined by the RIF Core Entailment Regime for the RIF rules geor:sfEquals, geor:sfDisjoint, geor:sfIntersects, geor:sfTouches, geor:sfCrosses, geor:sfWithin, geor:sfContains and geor:sfOverlaps.

semx.p: Basic graph pattern matching shall use the semantics defined by the RIF Core Entailment Regime SPARQLENT for the RIF rules RIFCORE geor:sfEqualsgeor:sfEquals, geor:sfDisjointgeor:sfDisjoint, geor:sfIntersectsgeor:sfIntersects, geor:sfTouchesgeor:sfTouches, geor:sfCrossesgeor:sfCrosses, geor:sfWithingeor:sfWithin, geor:sfContainsgeor:sfContains and geor:sfOverlapsgeor:sfOverlaps.

semx.p: Basic graph pattern matching shall use the semantics defined by the RIF Core Entailment Regime SPARQLENT for the RIF rules RIFCORE geor:ehEqualsgeor:ehEquals, geor:ehDisjointgeor:ehDisjoint, geor:ehMeetgeor:ehMeet, geor:ehOverlapgeor:ehOverlap, geor:ehCoversgeor:ehCovers, geor:ehCoveredBygeor:ehCoveredBy, geor:ehInsidegeor:ehInside and geor:ehContainsgeor:ehContains.

This clause defines Requirements for the RCC8 relation family. Table 11 specifies the function and property substitutions for each rule in the RCC8 relation family.
